course.subject: MATH
course.name: Honors Mathematical Analysis
course.description: The MATH 2043 and 3043 is a rigorous sequence in analysis on the line and higher dimensional Euclidean spaces. Limit, continuity, least upper bound axiom, open and closed sets, compactness, connectedness, differentiation, uniform convergence, and generalization to higher dimensions. Enrollment in the course requires approval of the course instructor.
course.prerequisites: Grade A in AL Pure Mathematics; or grade A- or above in MATH 1014/MATH 1020/MATH 1024

reviews.author: Jeff Sun
reviews.title: Difficult but Rewarding
reviews.comment_content: Analytical contents related to limits, functions, integrals, series. Some contents related to ODE was also added. Very rewarding.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor gives lectures well-prepared. He gives proofs of many important theorems which is very rewarding. He may also extend to some other contents which are not covered by the textbook, helping us build a complete knowledge system.
The tutorials, however, are messy, until the professor decided to give the tutorials in person. The TA makes the problems confusing by typos and will never correct them, making it impossible to understand (Yes they are critical ones!), and it seems that he looks down upon us and is only showing off his mathematical skills with a facial expression as if we owe him 1000000 dollars.
reviews.comment_grading:
Prof. A0's courses have good grades. He will dispell any worries about GPA when you take his courses. As soon as you take the course seriously, you will get a good grade.
Grading scheme: Several different percentage distributions and the highest scheme will be counted. So it does not matter if you perform unwell in one of the exams or homework.
He will also give us bonuses.
Due to my bad performance in midterm and homework, my grade is around the median of the class but I still got an A. He does absolute grading anyway, 75 is sure to have an A range but in practice, it seems that ~72 is enough.
Thank you, Prof. A0.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite large, especially if want to practice with problems in the textbooks.
But it is bound to give you a solid understanding of the course materials

reviews.comment_grading:
Total score = sup{a*homework + b*midterm + c*final: a \in [0, 0.2], b \in [0, 0.4], c \in [0.4, 0.7], a+b+c=1} + Bonus

Bonus (sup{Bonus} = 3)
- Latex per Homework = +0.2
- Answer questions in lectures (√ = +0.2, GG = +0.05 per Q)
- Provide solutions for the lecture notes exercise = +0.1
- Extra Problem Set = +1

"Whoever doesn't understand this formula, you better go to 2033" ---- FF

Total score >95% will guarantee an A+
Total score >80% will guarantee an A
Total score >75% will guarantee an A-

FF's exam is pretty standard. The key ideas of the exam questions were based on his problem sets. It is not hard to get an A range as long as you understand the idea of the homework.

"If you did not do as well as expected, note that the course total is calculated using an optimization scheme. It is possible to weigh HW 20%, Midterm 10% and Final 70%. Try to keep up in final. As 陶淵明 said 「悟已往之不諫，知來者之可追。」 -- which laterally means that you should understand the past (i.e. midterm) cannot be changed, but you know you can catch up in the future (i.e. final)." ---- FF

reviews.author: Doraemon
reviews.title: A challenging yet wonderful expedition in Analysis
reviews.comment_content:
The course mainly covers elementary analysis, following the first five chapters of the textbook Advanced Analysis written by Prof. Min Yan. Chapters 1 to 8 of Rudin's Principle of Mathematical Analysis is also a good reference to read for this course. Topics covered include:

1. Limit and continuity
2. Derivative and differentiability
3. Riemann integrals and Darboux integrals
4. Uniform convergence
5. Existence Theorems of ODEs (Picard's Iteration, Picard-Lindelof's Existence Theorem, Arzela-Ascoli's Theorem and Peano's Existence Theorem)

The last part is added by Prof. Fong, following Chapter 2 of his own ODE lecture notes.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching was excellent! Prof. Fong is very well prepared and he presented the course material in a logical and coherent way, making it easy to understand. He also proves almost all the theorems and proposition he has written down in class. In his lecture, the motivations of defining concepts and idea of proofs are very well explained.

In my opinion, the best thing Prof. Fong did in his explanation is that he always starts with a sketch or a graph, which gives us great geometric intuition to the proof before actually writing down the proof using abstract concepts.

The only disastrous thing about the course is the TA. I would say anyone who can fully understand his explanation deserves a Field's medal. I am super grateful that Prof. Fong was willing to teach the tutorial in person.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are a few grading schemes, from which the one giving the maximum score will be taken into consideration in determining the final course grade. In order words, you can skip all the homework if you can do very well in exams. On top of this, 1% bonus point is given to students who type up their homework using LaTex.

The grading is quite good. Two-thirds of the class got A range. I am grateful for getting an A despite poor performance in midterm and satisfactory performance in the final.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite heavy.

First of all, there is a biweekly homework (altogether 5 problem sets were assigned throughout the semester). While this sounds a piece of cake, it is not the case as each problem requires deep thought before you can come up with the solution. Discussing the problems with a friend helps a lot.

However, finishing the problem set is definitely inadequate for you to get a decent grade. So some extra practice from other books. This may take up quite a lot of your self studying time.

reviews.author: overloadtension
reviews.title: horror analysis 1
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1-5 in Yan Min's analysis notes
Additional topics with Ivan's self notes: Arzela-Ascoli thm, some applications to ODE, Stone-Weierstrass thm

This basically matches the philosophy stated in first lecture:
1. complete the gaps in MATH 1023/24 (Axiom of completeness, uniform continuity, basic topology in R)
2. integration (Riemamn integration, Darboux integration, Riemamn-Stieltjes integration)
3. uniform convergence (exchange of limits, differentiate/integrate series term by term)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ivan is always prepared and organizes contents very well. It is very easy to follow his teaching in class. I also like the way he challenges everybody by his tests. Finally, lovely drawing:).

In zoom meeting, Ivan would read out every private math question and explain it to everyone so there is no need to ask private math question:)

The TA also did very well. The contents in tutorials are very useful. His explanations and handwritten solutions are quite clear. Also, he is very responsive in the discord group.
reviews.comment_grading:
Scoring system thoroughly explained in another review. Note that this "flexible" formula turn out be only 10% flexibility between the higher score of midterm and final due to the difficulty of Ivan's exams.

Exams are open-book, open-internet, just don't post the questions in any forum

There is an "interesting" hint system in the final exam. If you audit this course, you can enjoy the final exam with these hints. People who desperately need hints may get taunted:(

The final grades are so lenient that half of the class get an A.

P.S. the bonus scores are calculated before giving out the grades, which is different from some CSE courses
reviews.comment_workload:
5 HW, one for each chapter, 10 problems each
LaTex typing gives 0.5 bouns points each

The difficulty of hw problems is appropriate since most questions requires some thinking while not being too tricky. Many problems are famous results that you can search online.
There is no way to say there that is a lot of hw since the amount of hw in Ivan's courses should be 1023 ~= 1024 > 2131 > 2043
Therefore the major workload comes from the time required to understand the contents and compile appropriate exercises (such as worksheets, tutorials and exercises in Yan Min's note especially if you feel lost in Math 1023/24)

reviews.author: Friday
reviews.comment_content:
For the major components of the course it sticks to Min Yan's lecture notes "Advanced Analysis", covering the first five chapters:
1. Limit of Sequence | Supremum, Infimum, Bolzano-Weierstrass and Set of Limits including Upper and Lower Limits
2. Limit of Function | Including Compactness and Connectedness Properties
3. Differentiation | Linear and High Order Approximation in terms of unit functions
4. Integration | Riemann, Darboux and Lebesgue Integration (additional topic) including the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
5. Topics in Analysis |Improper Integration, Series, Uniform Convergence and Exchange of Limits including some applications to IVP and Peano’s Existence Theorem (additional topics)
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Fong will mostly discuss the ideas behind the proofs of the theorems used, and will occasionally cover additional topics with a slightly different intuition from those of the lecture notes. These ideas will prove to be very useful on the homework and the exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good grading, ~2/3 of the students obtain A-range, lowest grade is C/C+ and will only be issued on exeptionally low performance. refer to the attachment for details.
The Total grade is defined as the maximum of the following sum
S(x,y,z) = x*Homework + y*Mindterm + z*Final
where (x, y, z) are either (0, 0.4, 0.6), (0, 0.3, 0.7), (0.2, 0.4, 0.4), or (0.2, 0.1, 0.7).
reviews.comment_workload: Medium workload. One homework every two week which will take around 9-12 hours to complete, not accounting for the time it takes to review the materials. Bonus marks will be given for submitting it on Latex (0.2% / HW) but doing so will significantly increase this time. The exam problems are somehow similar to the homework so you are highly encouraged to at least go over the solutions to every homework problem.

reviews.author: Mauricio
reviews.comment_content:
This class covers the first five chapters of Professor's Yan 'Advanced Analysis' lecture notes:

Limit of Sequence
Limit of Function
Differentiation
Integration
Topics in Analysis

The topics have some intersection with those in the honors version of the calculus courses(which prepare you for this class even more since the same professor wrote both lecture notes), but there is plenty of new things in the class and is more rigorous. Finally note it is possible to take this class together with MATH1024.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Yan teaches at an accelerated pace with some stops in between. In my opinion he does the teaching pretty well by balancing theory and examples and not rewriting the lecture notes as some Professors tend to do.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is not the best part of the course. A mean grade, around 80, will let you near the cut off between B and B+. Many good students also take this course making getting a good grade pretty hard. Grading was based on 20%HW, 30% Midterm and 50% Final.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload of the course is very heavy with around 15 exercises each week some of them could be pretty difficult going through the last 2 chapters.

reviews.author: qwertyyuiop
reviews.comment_content: The teaching content is really good. Since this course is related to Honor Real Analysis, the professor combine the similar parts of them and reorganize the course material. If you have the will to learn more about analysis, you will enjoy this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor taught good most of the times. He will demonstrate all proofs on the witheboard, and leave students to think for a while after finishing one proof.

The tutorials were also led by the professor. He will show some typical exercises in the lecture notes, and answer students' questions.

But here are some times that are not so good. For instance, he will sometimes go beyond the course and talk about topology, which is really hard to follow. And for those who did not take the previous honor courses MATH1023, MATH1024, taking his class may be a problem since he will just skip what he had taught in previous honor classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite fair, though not as good as that in MATH2033. There will be one midterm, one final and around 10 weekly homework. There will be 5 questions in both midterm and final. And mean of both midterm and final will be around 60/100.

It is not easy to get good grades sincec there is lots of advanced students in this class. If you are quite good at proofs, you will have a bigger chance to get a range. But if you are not good at these or if you missed previous honor courses, you will very likely to get b range or worse. So be careful whether to take this course or not.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is mainly on the weekly homework, which may take you most of your spare time through the whole week. And the same as revision. Be prepared for high workload.
